pageData.text: In this investigation, students will use basic scientific measuring equipment to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> and uncertainty associated with measurements using common laboratory glassware.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance - 20 minutes
Activity 2: Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware - 20 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance - 20 minutes
Activity 2: Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware - 20 minutes
Overview Video

text: Determine the uncertainty of measurements with <button class='glossary-text'>standard</button> glassware and equipment.
Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> of measurements with standard glassware.
Define accuracy and <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> as they pertain to measurements.
Identify different types of <button class='glossary-text'>errors</button> that may affect accuracy and precision of measurements.
Apply the mathematical concept of <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button> to measurements.

pageData.text: Communication is paramount in the scientific community because reproducibility is what establishes the theories and laws we recognize within the various scientific disciplines. If presented theories cannot be reproduced by scientists across the globe, they will not be confirmed. And scientists cannot reproduce an experiment if the conditions, procedures, and results are not clearly communicated via terminology every scientist understands. The General Conference on Weights and Measures began creating a common language among scientists when they defined the International System of Units, abbreviated SI (from the French Le Systeme International d’Unites). You can consider the SI system as the modern form of the metric system. The SI system is the only system of measurement that is officially recognized in nearly every country in the world. When reporting measurements, <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button> complement the SI units by allowing scientists to recognize how precise a reported answer is, or how much uncertainty there is within reported results. This also allows scientists to immediately gauge whether their equipment is capable of accurately reproducing the reported values of an experiment.

pageData.desc: Five scientists in lab coats posing as if in the middle of a discussion in a laboratory setting.
pageData.altText: Five scientists in lab coats posing as if in the middle of a discussion in a laboratory setting.

pageData.text: is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known to its true value. Having measurable results is an integral part of the scientific method. Scientists must contend with two main factors while taking measurements: the accuracy of the measurement and the of the measurement. Accuracy is how close a set of data is to the actual value. Precision refers to how close datum is to other measurements in a data set.

A data set that is accurate is not necessarily precise, whereas a very precise data set could be highly inaccurate (See Figure 1). Forces that affect the accuracy and precision in measurements are <button class='glossary-text'>error</button>. In scientific settings, error is defined as the difference between the measured value and the actual value, where the actual value is a known value, sometimes referred to as a standard. Two main types of error exist: systematic and random.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Four targets with a series of 4 black dots on each, showing different levels of accuracy and precision
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Four targets with a series of 4 black dots on each, showing different levels of accuracy and precision

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Systematic error</button> is a type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction. Systematic error can be further divided into absolute and <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button>. Absolute error has both magnitude and direction and is represented as a discrete value. For example, if your alarm clock is slow by five minutes it has a systematic, absolute error. It is important to note that systematic errors are consistent. They produce either consistently large or consistently small errors in a fixed proportion. If you repeat the experiment with the same equipment, you will see the same error.
Each morning you will be getting up five minutes later than planned and dealing with the potential repercussions. Absolute can be calculated as shown in Equation 1.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: Absolute error equals begin absolute value measurement minus actual value end absolute value Absolute error equals begin absolute value 6 colon 35 minus 6 colon 40 end absolute value equals 5 minutes
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Absolute error equals begin absolute value measurement minus actual value end absolute value Absolute error equals begin absolute value 6 colon 35 minus 6 colon 40 end absolute value equals 5 minutes

pageData.text: The vertical bars shown above indicate that you take the absolute value of a calculation. An absolute value means the value inside the bars will always be positive.

There is a second type of <button class='glossary-text'>systematic error</button> called <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button>, or percent error, which is expressed as a percentage. One of the more common measuring devices with built-in percent error is the speedometer of a car. Most automobile manufacturers have a tolerance of ± 2% in their speedometers. This means that any given speedometer could read between 2% too slow or 2% too fast. If your speedometer reads 61 mph, while actually traveling 60 mph, the percent error is calculated using Equation 2.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: Relative error equals begin fraction begin absolute value measurement minus actual value over begin paren actual value end paren end fraction times 100 percent
pageData.altText: Equation 2: Relative error equals begin fraction begin absolute value measurement minus actual value over begin paren actual value end paren end fraction times 100 percent

pageData.desc: Relative error equals begin fraction begin absolute value measurement minus actual value over begin paren actual value end paren end fraction times 100 percent
pageData.altText: Relative error equals begin fraction begin absolute value measurement minus actual value over begin paren actual value end paren end fraction times 100 percent

pageData.text: Percent error (relative error) is used when comparing a measured value to a known . For example, if an experiment required a calculation of the speed of sound at a given temperature, you would use the calculation for percent error to compare your result to the accepted value for the speed of sound at the given temperature, since multiple experiments have confirmed this accepted value. If, however, your experiment requires you to measure or calculate a result using two different methods, you would calculate the percent difference. For example, you could measure the height of a building by dropping a golf ball from the roof and measuring the time, or you could stand on the ground a known distance from the base of the building and calculate the height using trigonometry. To see how close the values are to each other, you would calculate the percentage difference.

pageData.desc: Equation 3: percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over secondary fraction begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end secondary fraction end primary fraction end absolute value times 100 percent
pageData.altText: Equation 3: percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over secondary fraction begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end secondary fraction end primary fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

pageData.text: An important characteristic of systematic <button class='glossary-text'>error</button>, both absolute and relative, is that it can be either corrected or accounted for in future measurements as it has both direction and magnitude. With your alarm clock, you could change the time so that it was no longer 5 minutes fast; with the speedometer, you could mathematically correct for the <button class='glossary-text'>relative error</button> in future readings.

Although systemic error can be corrected for if discovered, <button class='glossary-text'>random error</button> has no pattern and is usually unavoidable. Through improved experimental design and best lab practices, random error can be reduced, but it can never be eliminated. The most common form of random error in a lab setting comes from the limitations of reading the equipment. This type of random error is most commonly referred to as uncertainty. Uncertainty is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence using measuring equipment.

One method for determining the uncertainty of an analog measuring device is to utilize the scale provided on the equipment. For example, in Figure 2, there are graduations (lines) every 0.1 mL on the 10 mL graduated cylinder. In Figure 2, the bottom of the meniscus is between the graduations of 6.7 and 6.8. In one case the volume is low, in another case it is high. This is how we know an instrument’s level of . Most people would read the volume as 6.75 mL. You can say with certainty that the water is between 6.70 and 6.80 mL, but many people would have difficulty determining a finer range of certainty.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: 10 milliliter graduated cylinder showing the miniscus
pageData.altText: Figure 2: 10 milliliter graduated cylinder showing the miniscus

pageData.text: A simple method for determining the measured value and the uncertainty is as follows:

pageData.desc:
Measured value equals begin fraction high interval plus low interval over 2 end fraction 

Measured value example:
6.75 equals begin fraction 6.80 plus 6.70 over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText:
Measured value equals begin fraction high interval plus low interval over 2 end fraction 

Measured value example:
6.75 equals begin fraction 6.80 plus 6.70 over 2 end fraction

pageData.desc:
Equation 4: Uncertainty formula:
Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText:
Equation 4: Uncertainty formula:
Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction

pageData.desc:
Uncertainty example:
0.05 equals begin fraction 6.80 minus 6.70 over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText:
Uncertainty example:
0.05 equals begin fraction 6.80 minus 6.70 over 2 end fraction

pageData.text: The measured value in this example would be 6.75 mL ± 0.05 mL. The ± 0.05 mL indicates with confidence that the actual value for this measurement is between 6.80 mL and 6.70 mL.

pageData.question: When measuring liquids, why should you make a reading at the bottom of the meniscus?

options.text: It will give the most accurate results.
It will give the most precise results.
It has absolute and relative error.
It will have a percentage of error.
It is not necessary to read liquids at the meniscus.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When viewed at eye level, reading a liquid sample at the bottom of the meniscus will give the most accurate results.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To measure a volume of liquid, typically a piece of glassware, such as a beaker or graduated cylinder, is used. The equipment is placed on a flat countertop or table, and liquid is poured into it. The bottom of the meniscus (the concave layer of water at the top) is where the volume is measured against the scale. As you will see in Activities 2 and 4, the volume you read from a particular piece of glassware may be at best an estimate. Having measurable results is an integral part of the scientific method. Scientists must contend with two main factors while taking measurements: the accuracy of the measurement and the precision of the measurement. Accuracy is how close a set of data is to the actual value. It is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value.

img.alt: Figure 2: 10 milliliter graduated cylinder showing the miniscus

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: To measure a volume of liquid, typically a piece of glassware, such as a beaker or graduated cylinder, is used. The equipment is placed on a flat countertop or table, and liquid is poured into it. The bottom of the meniscus (the concave layer of water at the top) is where the volume is measured against the scale. As you will see in Activities 2 and 4, the volume you read from a particular piece of glassware may be at best an estimate. Having measurable results is an integral part of the scientific method. Scientists must contend with two main factors while taking measurements: the accuracy of the measurement and the precision of the measurement. Accuracy is how close a set of data is to the actual value. It is gauged by comparing the measured value of a known standard to its true value.

img.alt: Figure 2: 10 milliliter graduated cylinder showing the miniscus

pageData.text: With a digital device, such as the balance supplied in your equipment kit, uncertainty is generally calculated using a <button class='glossary-text'>standard</button> and a high number of measurements. A standard is a chemical or piece of equipment that has a known quantity associated with it, in this case a mass. For example, Figure 3 shows the official kilogram, a cylinder of vacuum-stored platinum-iridium alloy weighing exactly 1 kilogram that is used to standardize measurements. For this activity, plastic cups are used as your standard for determining the uncertainty in your balance.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: The international standard for the kilogram. A cylinder-shaped alloy of platinum and iridium, located in Sevres, Frances.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The international standard for the kilogram. A cylinder-shaped alloy of platinum and iridium, located in Sevres, Frances.

pageData.text:
, uncertainty, and equipment segue into the mathematical concept of . Significant figures are digits relating to the of measurement. There are some general rules for determining if a digit is significant.
  • All non-zero digits are considered significant.
  • Zeros appearing anywhere between two non-zero digits are significant; for example, 1,003 has 4 significant figures.
  • Leading zeros are not significant; for example, 0.0076 has 2 significant figures.
  • Trailing zeros in a number containing a decimal point are significant. For example, 35.000 has five significant figures.
Uncertainty limits the precision and the number of significant figures in a measurement. In the example above, the 6.75 mL of water in the graduated cylinder has three significant figures. The 6 before the decimal and the 7 and 5 after the decimal are all considered significant. This is confirmed with the uncertainty of 0.05 mL. In this instance, the uncertainty indicates that there are no additional significant figures beyond the hundredths place. However, if the graduated cylinder was measured at a volume of 6.75 mL, but the uncertainty was determined to be 0.20 mL, the number of significant figures would be limited to two, and the measurement would be reported as 6.8 mL ± 0.2 mL.
In the next example, let’s assume that the volume measurement above (6.75 mL) had a relative of 1%.

pageData.desc: 6.75 milliliters times begin fraction 1 percent over 100 percent end fraction equals 0.0675 milliliters
pageData.altText: 6.75 milliliters times begin fraction 1 percent over 100 percent end fraction equals 0.0675 milliliters

pageData.text: This would equate to an absolute error of 0.0675 mL in the measurement. Like 6.75 mL, 0.0675 mL has three <button class='glossary-text'>significant figures</button>. However, the process of multiplication and division has added a false <button class='glossary-text'>precision</button> to the result. 6.75 mL ±0.0675 mL is incorrect because the calculated error has additional precision than the original measurement can contain. In this instance, the proper measured value would be written as 6.75 mL ± 0.06 mL. In general, you cannot gain significant figures and you cannot gain precision in a measurement through mathematical functions.

Measurements can be found all around us, and they are often taken for granted. If you feel sick, for example, you may take your temperature using a thermometer. The thermometer is the tool used to measure your temperature. If you want to take some liquid medicine to feel better, you may measure the amount in a small measuring cup. Pouring the amount accurately is essential to your feeling better and your well-being.

If you like to bake, proper measurement is essential to get the best results. If you do not mix with the correct ratios of ingredients, you will get flat, thin, crispy cookies instead of fluffy, thick, scrumptious ones.

Other examples of everyday measurements are picking out the clothes you wear, estimating what time you need to leave your house to make it to work on time, and how much fuel you need to put in your car to make it to your destination.

pageData.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement shown below?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The uncertainty is 0.1 mL and the observed measurement is 3.6 mL, therefore there are three significant figures.

imageData.desc: A 15 mL conical vial with graduation lines every 0.5 mL. The vial is filled with 3.6 mL of liquid.
imageData.altText: A 15 mL conical vial with graduation lines every 0.5 mL. The vial is filled with 3.6 mL of liquid.

pageData.question: How many significant figures are in this number 0.0853?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Leading zeros are not significant, therefore 0.0853 has three significant figures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Error, uncertainty, and equipment segue into the mathematical concept of significant figures. Significant figures are digits relating to the precision of measurement. There are some general rules for determining if a digit is significant.
  • All non-zero digits are considered significant.
  • Zeros appearing anywhere between two non-zero digits are significant; for example, 1,003 has 4 significant figures.
  • Leading zeros are not significant; for example, 0.0076 has 2 significant figures.
  • Trailing zeros in a number containing a decimal point are significant. For example, 35.000 has five significant figures.
Uncertainty limits the precision and the number of significant figures in a measurement. In the example discussed, the 6.75 mL of water in the graduated cylinder has three significant figures. The '6' before the decimal and the '7' and '5' after the decimal are all considered significant. This is confirmed with the uncertainty of 0.05 mL. In this instance, the uncertainty indicates that there are no additional significant figures beyond the hundredth place. However, if the graduated cylinder was measured at 6.75 but the uncertainty was determined to be 0.20 mL, the number of significant figures would be limited to two and the measurement would be reported as 6.8 mL ± 0.2 mL.

Error, uncertainty, and equipment segue into the mathematical concept of significant figures. Significant figures are digits relating to the precision of measurement. There are some general rules for determining if a digit is significant.
  • All non-zero digits are considered significant.
  • Zeros appearing anywhere between two non-zero digits are significant; for example, 1,003 has 4 significant figures.
  • Leading zeros are not significant; for example, 0.0076 has 2 significant figures.
  • Trailing zeros in a number containing a decimal point are significant. For example, 35.000 has five significant figures.
Uncertainty limits the precision and the number of significant figures in a measurement. In the example discussed, the 6.75 mL of water in the graduated cylinder has three significant figures. The '6' before the decimal and the '7' and '5' after the decimal are all considered significant. This is confirmed with the uncertainty of 0.05 mL. In this instance, the uncertainty indicates that there are no additional significant figures beyond the hundredth place. However, if the graduated cylinder was measured at 6.75 but the uncertainty was determined to be 0.20 mL, the number of significant figures would be limited to two and the measurement would be reported as 6.8 mL ± 0.2 mL.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will label washers 1 and 2 and measure their masses 5 times each for each washer. Then, you will determine the average mass of each washer and the deviation from the average for each washer and each trial. In activity 2, you will measure the mass of a glassware item. Then, you will add the target volume of water to the glassware item and record the highest and lowest volume intervals. Next, you will calculate the uncertainty. Then, you will measure the mass of the glassware item with water. You will repeat this process for another glassware item. Finally, you will calculate the mass of the water in each glassware item.  In Activity 3, you will record the current room temperature. Then you will calculate the water volumes for the volumes measured in activity 2 using density. Next, you will compare the measured and calculated water volumes. Finally, you will repeat this for the second glassware item trials.

pageData.text: Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before starting the activity. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is true of accuracy and precision?

options.text: Accuracy is how close a data point is to the actual value while precision is how close a data point is to other measurements in the data set.
Accuracy is how close a data point is to other measurements in the data set while precision is how close a data point is to the actual value.
Accuracy is how close a data point is to the actual value while precision is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence.
Accuracy is precision is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence while precision is how close a data point is to other measurements in the data set.
Accuracy is precision is the limit of quantifiable measurement with confidence while precision is the known value used to establish uncertainty.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following will be present in all measurements?

You take your dog to the vet, where he is weighed at 10.3 kg. When you get him home, you weigh him on your bathroom scale, where he appears to weigh 11.2 kg. Assuming that the veterinarian's scale has measured your dog's actual weight, what is the absolute error?
An object is known to be 10.0 cm in length, but is measured to be 9.9 cm. What is the percent error in this measurement?
A ruler is marked every 1 millimeter. You measure the length of an object to be between 5.9 cm and 6.0 mm. What is the measured value with confidence interval for this object?
Which of the following best describes the actual value for a quantity measuring 10.4 g ± 0.1 g?

options.text: The actual value is between 10.3 g and 10.5 g.
The actual value is less than 10.4 g.
The actual value is more than 10.4 g.
The actual value is exactly 10.4 g.
The actual value is exactly 10.5 g.

assestmentData.question: During an experiment, you collect data in the following table. What is the deviation from the average for Trial 2?
This investigation uses a glass thermometer. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

Read through the activities.
Clear the work space.
Obtain all materials and set up for the lab activity.
In Activity 1, you will conduct multiple trials of measuring washers with the lab balance and then calculate the deviation from the average to determine the uncertainty of the lab balance.

pages.title:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Lab Balance (11 steps)

pageData.text: Turn on your balance and allow the reading to stabilize at 0.0. If the balance does not read 0.0, press the tare button.
Label two large metal washers as “1” and “2.”
Place Washer 1 on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Remove the washer from the balance and allow the balance to restabilize at 0.0.
Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for four additional readings.
Place Washer 2 on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Remove the washer from the balance and allow the balance to restabilize at 0.0.
Repeat Steps 6 and 7 for four additional readings.
Determine the average mass of each washer and record the value in Data Table 1. (Remember, the average is the sum of the mass of all trials, divided by the number of trials.)
For each trial, perform the following calculation:
deviation from average = | average mass of washer – mass of washer in trial |
Calculate the average deviation from average for each washer and record this value in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will compare the mass of the same volume of water measured in the graduated cylinder and the beaker to determine the uncertainty of this lab glassware. You will use the mass of water in each container in Activity 3.

pages.title:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Uncertainty in Common Glassware (11 steps)

pageData.text: Turn on your balance and allow the reading to stabilize at 0.0. If the balance does not read 0.0, press the tare button.
Place the 250 mL graduated cylinder on the balance and record the mass in Data Table 2.
Remove the graduated cylinder from the balance.
Fill the graduated cylinder with approximately 50 mL of water.
Record the volume of water in Data Table 2.
Note: The volumes in Step 5 are high confidence estimates; i.e., you are sure that the true value is between the high volume and low volume.

Record the highest and lowest volume interval in Data Table 2. These should be volumes that you are certain the actual volume is between. Use the graduations (lines) on the glassware to help determine the higher and lower interval.
Calculate the uncertainty of your measurement.

pageData.desc: Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText: Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction

pageData.text: Zero the balance, and record the mass of the graduated cylinder with water in Data Table 2.
Repeat Steps 1–8 with the graduated cylinder for one additional trial.
Repeat Steps 1–8 with the 250 mL beaker.
Calculate the mass of water in each piece of glassware and record the mass in Data Tables 2 and 3.
Mass of water = mass of glassware with water - mass of empty glassware

In Activity 3, you will use the density of water and the mass of water in each container measured in Activity 2 to calculate the volume of water in each container. You will use this to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>accuracy</button> this lab glassware.

pages.title:
A
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (5 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Accuracy in Common Glassware (5 steps)

pageData.text: With the thermometer, record the current water temperature in Data Table 3.
Using Table 1, record the density of water at the current water temperature in Data Table 3.
Calculate the volume of water using the density for the current water temperature from Data Table 3.
Remember: density = mass/volume
Calculate the percent difference between the volume of water in Activity 2 (50 mL) and the value calculated for the volume of water in Activity 3.

pageData.desc: percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over secondary fraction begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end secondary fraction end primary fraction end absolute value times 100 percent
pageData.altText: percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over secondary fraction begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end secondary fraction end primary fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

pageData.text: Repeat Step 4 with the 250 mL beaker using the target volume in Data Table 2.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.desc:
Equation 4: Uncertainty formula:
Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction
pageData.altText:
Equation 4: Uncertainty formula:
Uncertainty equals begin fraction high interval minus low interval over 2 end fraction

pageData.desc: Figure 3: The international standard for the kilogram. A cylinder-shaped alloy of platinum and iridium, located in Sevres, Frances.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The international standard for the kilogram. A cylinder-shaped alloy of platinum and iridium, located in Sevres, Frances.

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will label washers 1 and 2 and measure their masses 5 times each for each washer. Then, you will determine the average mass of each washer and the deviation from the average for each washer and each trial. In activity 2, you will measure the mass of a glassware item. Then, you will add the target volume of water to the glassware item and record the highest and lowest volume intervals. Next, you will calculate the uncertainty. Then, you will measure the mass of the glassware item with water. You will repeat this process for another glassware item. Finally, you will calculate the mass of the water in each glassware item.  In Activity 3, you will record the current room temperature. Then you will calculate the water volumes for the volumes measured in activity 2 using density. Next, you will compare the measured and calculated water volumes. Finally, you will repeat this for the second glassware item trials.

pageData.title: Table 1.
pageData.content: Table 1. Density versus temperature of water

data.title: Accuracy
data.content: The measure of how close a set of data is to the actual value

data.title: Error
data.content: The difference between the measured value and the actual value, which is known

data.title: Precision
data.content: A measure of how close a datum is to other measurements in a data set

data.title: Random error
data.content: Error that is present in all measurements and is usually unavoidable; includes uncertainty

data.title: Relative error
data.content: A systematic error expressed as a percentage; also called percent error

data.title: Significant figures
data.content: Digits relating to the precision of measurement

data.title: Standard
data.content: A chemical or piece of equipment that has a known quantity associated with it

data.title: Systematic error
data.content: A type of error that causes measurements to be inaccurate by a certain value in a particular direction
